title: 112_s548
content: The Act is titled the "Effective Interrogation of Unprivileged Enemy Belligerents Act" and includes procedures for the interrogation of certain terrorist detainees. The "Effective Interrogation of Unprivileged Enemy Belligerents Act" requires the Secretary of Defense, Director of National Intelligence, and Attorney General to submit procedures for interrogating enemy belligerents with significant information. This includes those under US control or foreign entities providing access for interrogation. The procedures must establish an entity for this purpose. The "Effective Interrogation of Unprivileged Enemy Belligerents Act" mandates the creation of an entity comprising representatives from various intelligence agencies to interrogate enemy belligerents suspected of holding valuable information. The criteria for identifying such individuals and the presumption that the entity will conduct the interrogations are outlined in the act. The "Effective Interrogation of Unprivileged Enemy Belligerents Act" establishes a process for interrogating enemy belligerents suspected of possessing valuable information, with specific procedures for those located inside or outside the United States. The Director of the FBI or CIA, in consultation with the Defense Intelligence Agency, can determine if security concerns prevent interrogation. The "Effective Interrogation of Unprivileged Enemy Belligerents Act" allows for the designation of individuals in custody as unprivileged enemy belligerents for interrogation by the Secretary of Defense. The process includes access to detainees regardless of their location. The Act allows for the designation of individuals as unprivileged enemy belligerents for interrogation by the Secretary of Defense, with priority given to obtaining timely intelligence over criminal prosecution. Access to detainees is ensured regardless of their location. The Act allows for the interrogation of unprivileged enemy belligerents for intelligence collection, with procedures for determining their status and disposition. Exceptions to the procedures can only be authorized by specific authorities. The Effective Interrogation of Unprivileged Enemy Belligerents Act allows for interrogation of such individuals located outside the US by the CIA Director in consultation with the Defense Intelligence Agency Director. The Director of National Intelligence must provide the identities of interrogated or determined unprivileged enemy belligerents to the Senate and House Intelligence Committees every 180 days. The Secretary of Defense, in coordination with the Director of National Intelligence and the Attorney General, must submit any modifications to interrogation procedures to Congress 60 days before they take effect. If an exception to the procedures is authorized during an interrogation of an unprivileged enemy belligerent, Congress must be notified within ten days. The term 'appropriate committees of Congress' refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term 'intelligence community' is defined as per the National Security Act of 1947. 'Interrogation' includes questioning methods. The term 'interrogation' includes custodial debriefings of unprivileged enemy belligerents suspected of possessing significant information for intelligence collection. The term 'unprivileged enemy belligent' is defined in section 2256(a) of title 28, United States Code.
